results.title: Rush hour space age
results.creator_credit: Space Age Images and Litton Industries
results.brief_description: What is the solution to the problem of the automobile which is threatening to kill cities and their inhabitants? This film proposes that mass transportation systems are the answer and demonstrates that Chicago, New York and London are doing something about it by improving the efficiency and economy of existing systems. Some must take more drastic action. For Example, San Francisco, has set up a rapid transport system authority to combat the problem. Mention is made of the first automatic public transport ticketing system.

results.title: Rush hour
results.brief_description: From 08:20 to 09:20 the commuters pour into London’s Waterloo Station. Using speed photography and the sound of the clicking clock, this hour has been effectively compressed into three minutes adding extra momentum to the rush hour at Waterloo Station.

results.title: Rusalka
results.creator_credit: Landseer Film and Television Productions, RM Arts, David Pountney and Derek Bailey
results.brief_description: Lyrical fairytale in three acts of a water-nymph who falls in love with a human prince by Antonin Dvorak, libretto by Jaroslav Kvapil, produced by David Pountney and performed at the London Coliseum by the English National Opera Orchestra and Chorus conducted by Mark Elder. Features Eilene Hannan (Rusalka), John Treleaven (the Prince), Rodney Macann (the Water Spirit), Ann Howard (Jezibaba), Phyllis Cannan (the Foreign Princess), along with Cathryn Pope, Eileen Hulse, and Linda McLeod as the Wood-Nymphs. The simple but effective Victorian nursery setting with its fairytale atmosphere is designed by Stephanos Lazaridis.

results.title: Rural nurse: a pilot project in El Salvador
results.brief_description: The story of the setting up and organisation of a demonstration area as part of the El Salvador Nursing Program, which is a plan to tackle simultaneously problems of food, health, education and living standards.

results.title: Rural life of Mexico
results.brief_description: A study of the life of isolated communities in the mountains of Mexico. Living largely by agriculture and using methods of cultivation which have scarcely changed during the centuries, these Mexicans still wear their regional costumes unselfconsciously and dance at fiesta time their traditional dances.

results.title: Rural life in Western Ireland: Irish children
results.brief_description: A brother and sister in rural western Ireland help on the farm and in the house; they help to dig turf from the bog, and, together with their family, enjoy a picnic.

results.title: Rural Japan: helping to feed a nation
results.brief_description: Shows the everyday life of the average Japanese farmer, his home and surroundings. Also shows the effects of recent changes on his way of life - the cultivation of plants under hot house conditions, the use of tractors instead of hard manual labour and how rural life has changed since the War with the influence of America.

results.title: Rural industries
results.creator_credit: Motion Picture Associates, Film Australia, Peter Johnson and John Leake
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
Australia’s modern techniques of cultivation and harvesting are demonstrated to show how this country is a major supplier of grain to the world. The film also shows how the cattle and livestock industry supply food to most parts of the globe.

results.title: Rural and urban poverty: seeds of catastrophe
results.brief_description: Shows how catastrophe is likely to result from the shortfall in food production in developing countries. Looks at rural and urban poverty. Extract from “Five Minutes to Midnight”.

results.title: Rupert Murdoch
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Kip Porteous and Ken Hannam
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Five Australians”
Looks at the personal life of Rupert Murdoch the newspaper tycoon, whose career started when he inherited the family company interests. He expanded the business and launched a national paper, The Australian. Members of his family and staff discuss the man they know.
